div1.p: Carter comments on Williamson's manuscript, entitled "The Use of Fish for the Control of Mosquitoes."

div1.head: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter, [1924]
div1.p:
I want to add that this is a good paper: On the history of what has
been, and is being, done with fish control of mosquitoes a most excel-
lent one.

Would it not, however, have been better to have divided the sub-
ject squarely into two parts: Control of Anopheles and Control of Stego-
myia? Both the characteristics necessary in the fish themselves and the
measures the sanitarian must take in aid of the fish to render them ef-
ficient are frequently entirely different according to which of these
genera we wish to control:

For instance, since the aquatic forms of Anopheles are exclusively
surface dwellers, the fish for Anopheles control then should be (1) top-
feeders: And, since Anopheles breed almost exclusively in natural col-
lections of water and the larvae shelter themselves in vegetation and
floatage collected mainly around the edges of the water, the fish should
be (2) able to work themselves into such vegetation and floatage so as
to have access to the larvae. Since almost the only risk these fish are
exposed to (supposing the climate and water are suitable) is their des-
truction by larger fish, they should be (3) very small (hence as little
temptation as possible) and (4) inclined to frequent very shallow water
and so get out of the way of larger fish. Working their way into thick
vegetation and floatage is also a protection against larger fish.

About all that is required of, or is possible to, the sanitarian in
aid of fish-control of Anopheles (after stocking the breeding area proper-
ly) is to (a) so remove vegetation and floatage as to give the fish access
to the larvae and (b) to see that the laviporous fish are not destroyed
and to replace them when they are.

Stegomyia larvae, on the contrary, although they come to the top
for air, spend most of their time at the bottom: Hence either a bottom
or top-feeding fish may be (and indeed has been) efficient against them,
but the former would seem preferable.

Since Stegomyia, in the Americas, breeds practically only in artificial
containers, there is no question of access of fish pload in them to the larvae
(although larvae are reported as occasionally hiding in dark corners of
the container). There is therefor no need of characteristic (2) in fish
for Stegomyia control nor is there any need for the sanitarian to remove
protection for the larvae from the fish.

Fish used for Stegomyia control--i. e. in containers, are subject
to the following risks:
(1) Since only a few are allowed in each container, they must be
moved often for another hatchery to replace those that die.
(2) They are liable to jump out of the container, especially when
water is dipped out of it, or to be washed out when overflowing from rain.
(3) To be dipped out with the water.
(4) To be injured when the utensil, used for dipping water, is drop-
ped in.
(5) Injured by sudden change (fall) of temperature and
(6) Die for (or fail to thrive from insufficient) light.

Very obviously then, the measures to be taken by the sanitarian to
protect these fish and thus insure Stegomyia control, as well as the char-
acteristics necessary in the fish themselves, are very different from those
necessary for Anopheles control. In point of fact, while we all agree
that a very small top minnow is best for Anopheles control: practically all
the fish especially recommended for Stegomyia control by Connor: Hanson:
Dunn: Caldwell: Houle and Scannell have been bottom-feeders: many of them es-

pecially recommended on account of lessoned risk of (1) (i. e. tougher):
(2): (3): (4): (5)& (6) as enumerated in the last paragraph, as compared
with top minnows, which, however, have given good, although less good, re-
sults.

It seems to me then that a primary division into Control of Anopheles
Production and Control of Stegomyia (Aedes (Stegomyia) aegypti) Production
might have been better, with your geographical division following.

The Control of the brackish-marsh Aedes could have also differnetiated
to itself. It is an extensive problem, but simple--(fish: ditches and
tide-gates) and rarely a sanitary one, although we found letting in “Killi-
fish” both needed and efficient against A. crucians at Langly Field and vi-
cinity in Virginia (1918).

I think too, one might note that we have no fish very suitable for
the stream (and small pool) breeding of Anopheles--which is no small
sanitary problem.

About the only advantage I can see in using top-feeding fish in
artificial containers is that one can see them more readily on inspection
and thus know that they are alive. As, however, any fish when dead would
soon float up to the surface, not seeing the bottom-feeder on top would
would be good evidence that it was yet alive. In moderate sized containers
they would also be visible by a flash light.
